Award.AwardTitle: Student Grants to Attend the Symposium On Usable Privacy and Security 2016 (SOUPS 16); June 22-24, 2016; Denver, Colorado

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Usable security and privacy is increasingly recognized as an important aspect of the cybersecurity field. The Symposium On Usable Privacy and Security (SOUPS) brings together an interdisciplinary group of researchers and practitioners in human computer interaction, security, and privacy. The program features technical papers, workshops and tutorials, a poster session, panels and invited talks, and discussion sessions. The 12th SOUPS will be held June 22-24, 2016 in Denver CO. The funds support travel grants for students to attend the conference. SOUPS is the top conference devoted to usable privacy and security. By increasing student participation at the SOUPS conference, it may encourage more students to get involved in usable security research and pursue further graduate education and careers in this area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Twelfth Symposium on Usable Privacy and Security (SOUPS 2016) brought together an interdisciplinary group of researchers and practitioners in human computer interaction, security, and privacy. SOUPS 2016 featured a poster session, panels and invited talks, lightning talks and demos, and workshops and tutorials. SOUPS 2016 received 79 technical paper submissions, which resulted in 22 papers being selected for presentation and publication. SOUPS 2016 was co-located with the 2016 USENIX Annual Technical Conference. The conference was held in Denver, CO, from June 22–24, 2016. There were 153 total attendees at SOUPS 2016. Of these, the majority were from the U.S. Non-U.S. attendees came from: Austria, Brazil, Canada, Germany, India, Japan, Portugal, Puerto Rico, South Korea, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom. This grant provided funds for 12 masters and doctoral students from U.S. universities to atted the conference, including registration and travel expenses. Funded students were from the following universities: Indiana University Bloomington, Brigham Young University, Florida Institute of Technology, University of Texas at Arlington, University of Connecticut, Portland State University, University of North Carolina, Charlotte, University of California Berkeley, University of Maryland College Park, Carnegie Mellon University. Students awareded funding are conducting research in the usable privacy and security area.
